thread.title: Moving boxes, breaking records

author: DispatchDaemon
title: Moving boxes, breaking records
text:
Photos Photo by Stephen B. Morton for GPA Georgia Ports' set a new record for container traffic lin September. This demonstrated ability to handle high container volumes made Savannah the only U.S. port to rank in the Top 10 of the Journal of Commerce's annual listing of the Top 50 fastest-growing ports in the world, released last week. For months, Georgia Ports’ executive director Curtis Foltz has been noting the rise in container volumes with a modicum of caution.
When July numbers came in stronger than anticipated, Foltz tempered the announcement with a prediction that the growth would slow down.
“The crystal ball isn’t clear,” he said at the time. “But at some point soon, I expect this growth surge to slow as the last of the West Coast volumes that had been diverted shift back.”
He’s still waiting.
September numbers are out today and — ho hum — it’s another record-breaking month.
Last month the Port of Savannah handled 317,411 20-foot equivalent container units, a 7.3-percent increase over the same month last year, which was — in itself — a record shattering month.
“We are pleasantly surprised to see volumes remaining above last year’s double digit growth,” Foltz said, noting that September 2014 container numbers were nearly 13 percent higher than the same month in 2013, due in part to diverted cargo from the West Coast, where labor and management were struggling to forge a new agreement.
Still, he was quick to offer another caveat.
“Last month was the busiest September for container traffic in GPA’s history. We anticipate, at some point this year, to begin seeing throughput leveling off to more normal patterns,” he said.
That may well happen, but it’s no longer a secret that Savannah’s ability to handle the extra load has put it in a category of its own.
Across the logistics industry, focus has centered on Savannah as it continued to handle a massive influx of cargo throughout the spring and summer without becoming mired in congestion. This demonstrated ability to handle high container volumes made Savannah the only U.S. port to rank in the Top 10 of the Journal of Commerce’s annual listing of the Top 50 fastest-growing ports in the world, released last week.
Apparently, a lot of that diverted cargo came and decided to stay, something that doesn’t surprise GPA board chairman Jim Walters.
“New customers exposed to services through the Port of Savannah have found that they can reach the fast-growing southeastern U.S. market more efficiently through Georgia’s deepwater ports,” Walters said.
“Being the only American port to rank in the top 10 is testimony to GPA’s long-term commitment to customer service.”
Other September numbers were also positive, Foltz said, with roll-on/roll-off cargo topping 50,000 units, up 4.6 percent from the same month last year. Total tonnage was up 5 percent to 2.52 million tons in September.
Whale petition denied
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has issued a notice stating that it has denied a petition to exclude federally maintained dredged channels and pilot boarding areas for ports from New York to Jacksonville from the vessel speed restrictions that were established to reduce the threat of vessel collisions with North Atlantic right whales.
At Wednesday’s meeting of the Savannah Maritime Association, SMA board member Tom Wright expressed disappointment in the decision and concern that the extensive real-time reporting requirements placed on ships’ pilots provides an unnecessary distraction.
“It’s a real challenge to get on a ship, try to explain all these rules to the crew and do all the reporting required when your primary concern should be navigating the ship safely through the channel,” he said.
Wright said he has asked pilots to give him a breakdown of everything they have to deal with when boarding a ship.
“We’d like to put together some data that we can take to our congressional representatives,” he said.
Senior business reporter Mary Carr Mayle covers the ports for the Savannah Morning News and savannahnow. She can be reached at 912-652-0324 or at mary.mayle@savannahnow.com.
